about her brother and she was just saying he, that he's a practice homosexual. And she said,
and he loves Jesus. And so that's just so hard to go, no, he doesn't, because you don't want to do
that. Right. But it's a matter of, I don't know his level of love or his heart or things like that.
But I think it is important if someone is saying they're committed to Jesus, but they're sleeping
with their girlfriend or they're having an affair and they're like, but I still love Jesus.
I think there's, I think it's okay to, to bring up the issue of what do you think it means to
love Jesus? Yeah. And, and you know, cause people will say things like you had mentioned before,
um, earlier we were talking, can't we just agree to disagree? Yeah. And I liked your response,
which was, Oh, mine. Yeah. I mean, it is, it is a situation of agreement disagreement. It's just
that it just means we're disagreeing with God. Right. So it's like, yeah, this is an issue of
agree and disagree. I just disagree with God that this is sin. And he says it is. So it's, it's not,
it's, it's not always a good, no, it is always not a good idea to be in disagreement with God and then
just to take that stance, to make that argument. You know, that's not wise. Right. And, and, and I
think that is part of, you know, as messed up people, like I, I love Jesus and I give into sexual
immorality at times. Here's my, here's the other one. I think is intriguing is when we wrestle with
someone who just doesn't agree, like they authentically try to understand scripture and
their conclusion is different. Sorry. And I, I don't, I don't fully get that. I don't, you know,
I have tried to understand scripture in terms of that it does not call out the sin of homosexual
behavior. I don't know. It's hard to judge. I can't judge somebody else's motives. But it's,
it's, it is, I don't know. I think you referenced was a Tim Keller who said, if, if your God always
disagree, if your God always agrees with you, that you just have a deified version of yourself. Yeah.
And that's, it is, you know, there is something to that in that I actually would say when it comes
to homosexual behavior, God doesn't, God does not agree with me. I don't, I don't have that same
personal stance that God seems to, but he does. And so it's not necessary for me to agree with God.
When it comes to my own section, my own personal sexual temptations, God doesn't agree with me.
And so I still have to sacrifice those. And when I mess up, I have to, it certainly means in that
moment, I'm not loving Jesus sufficiently when I give into that sin. Fortunately, he holds on to me
even when I'm, he's faithful, even when I'm faithless. But I think it is always fair for us
to challenge each other in places that we, if we claim to be Christians, man, I was gonna find it
real quick, but that's actually the one population we're told we should be challenging is people who
claim the name of Christ, but who are living in a way that we think is the scripture teaches us sin.
That's the chapter before that was where Paul said that before he said, I'm not telling you to
not associate with people. There it is. You're right. It's right. He goes, because in that case,
you'd have to leave the world. Like you literally can't. But what he's talking about is people who
are bearing the name of brother, saying they're a Christian and they're blatantly living in sin.
That's where you have a problem where there's again, as we've said, there's a difference between
this is my struggle. This is my temptation versus this is what I'm doing. And I'm okay with it.
And you should be too. Well, and I think one thing that, like you've said before, that's helpful of
a helpful question to ask ourselves to see if we're being deceived is if, if scripture is agreeing
with what I want to think and what I like in this stance, you have to ask yourself, okay,
if scripture disagreed with me, would I still follow it? Yeah, exactly. And that's on any issue
of like, okay, yeah, I kind of like what scripture says. But if, if it didn't, if I didn't,
would I still be willing to follow Jesus? And sometimes that's a good, yes, a good question
to ask of, of, yeah, am I just worshiping a deified version of myself? Am I trying to twist scripture
because it's more comfortable? And it's not always the litmus test, but I think it's a good
question to ask. It's certainly people good. Well, people will say, but I don't feel convicted about
an issue. And even that is dangerous, is what it's saying is, unless I feel convicted, like,
I'm letting my feelings be the governor of how I live my life. Like, who do I do? I agree with
her, feel bad or not. It's like that. It doesn't matter what you feel about something. It's what
does it say? Yeah, that's a good point. Yeah, important truth there. So what are some of the
other cases that people make when they're, when they're, when they're deconstructing over these
sexual issues, when they're uncomfortable with it? And this is what, what inspires that? What
are some other cases that are made? Because it's not always scriptural. Yeah, I think people would
say it's like on a biblical basis, but not from an actual passage. And I think we've talked about
a lot of these before, just in passing, as we've talked about scripture. But I think one of them
that he will bring up a lot is that Christians have been on the wrong side of history before,
and equate it to something like slavery, where it's like, well, we've, we've had a stance before
that we've gone back on and realized we were wrong. That's one of them. Yeah. And there's no
way around that. Yes, that's true. Being wrong on something. That's, it's, that is a human tendency,
by the way, it's a psychological tendency for us, obviously, to when people seem to be crying wolf,
they make the same case. The problem is, as, as thinkers, as reasoners, we know,
that's, that's a form of the genetic fallacy, is when we say, because this, this information is
coming from somebody who was not right last time, that doesn't necessarily mean they're not right
this time. And we still have to discuss it on its own merits. What does the argument actually say?
What does the Bible actually say? What does the case actually say? Just, I mean, there are a lot
of people in Florida who just learned that when they, well, the last four times that they told us
to evacuate, it turned out not to be a big deal. And then it turned out to be a big deal. And I
didn't evacuate because well, the last four times we just, we really, you have to always be very,
very careful about that mindset. And yes, when I go back through the list, which I did one day,
when we talked about all the different steps of the sexual revolution, out of like 10 to 20 steps,
I would say, are there, there's three or four of them that I would say, yeah, we Christians took
the wrong side on that. And we were just wrong about that. Now, there's still Christians alive
today who disagree with me, like say on, on birth control. But I think the initial response of many
Christians was ended up being the wrong response when it came to birth control. Yeah. It's, I
understand why I see where it came from, I can see the misunderstandings or whatever. And I even
understand the argument. But in the end, I think, no, this was the wrong anyway. Yeah. But that
doesn't mean again, you can be wrong about 19 things in a row. And that doesn't mean you're
wrong on the 20th one. Yeah. I understand why they were treated dubiously. Oh, you guys aren't
always right. Yeah. Yes. Yeah. That's correct. And then the other part of it is like, okay, the,
the way that, yeah, some people treated and still treat people who, yeah, homosexual people.
And it's like, okay, well, that, that mistreatment is, is wrong. It's mistreatment.
But that is not what we're saying. The Bible. Right. It's not the same argument. Right. There's,
I think I read it. I read a quote that said there's a difference between a posture problem
and a theology problem. Yeah. So you have to differentiate between those two because they're
not the same. But yeah. On the problem with the wrong side of history, you could say that
about any issue, right? Like people were trying to make pedophilia. Okay. Well, you guys have been
on the wrong side of history before, right? You can, you can say that about any particular,
anyone from that list of first Corinthians, you know, you can say, well, how do you know you're
right this time? And so that's why, again, I think what you just said, Chris, is so true that a
careful, honest studying of the passage means this is where you're going to land. I think with those
other issues, you can look back and go like the slavery piece, like, let me show you where you got
off track. And this is, this is where they were abusing this verse. So this is what this isn't
what it meant. This is a great example where it's like, it's really clear. And I think you just
don't like the conclusion, but yeah. Yeah. I think two of the other arguments that I hear probably
the most is, and I think we've addressed both of them, but just briefly, I was born this way. And
then aren't we just called to love are two really common ones. And like we've talked about, I was,
I was just born this way. It's like, yeah, we were. I mean, yes, that's right. I think the argument
is made a lot more complicated than, than it has to be because the, the world would say I was born
this way. And therefore it is true to who I am. And it's right. Or, and even could make the argument
of it's wrong for me not to act in this way. And then the Christian ethic on all fronts said, yes,
I was born this way. I was born in sin and brokenness, and that affects all of me. And so
that argument doesn't leave when we just talk about a aspect of sexuality.
Yes. Yeah. That's a, I remember when I, so I'm old enough to remember when this was a,
when this, when the argument, the question of homosexuality became the frontline of the
sexual revolution. And it was super common to have people on the progressive side of the argument
say, God wouldn't, or people on the, excuse me, people on the Christian side say, well,
God wouldn't make someone gay. And, and then the people on the homosexual side, the progressive
side of the argument saying, no, God, I made this way. I was born this way. I was, God made me this
way or whatever the argument was. And James Dobson was the first person who, because he was trained
as a psychologist and as a, you know, a PhD, not as a theologian, not as a, and when someone asked
him that in a, in a discussion situation, he said, well, of course, I mean, it's not the one magical
sin humans can't be born with. I mean, it's a fundamental belief of Christianity that we are
born broken. And so why would this be the one sin, the one brokenness you can't be born with?
Of course you could be born with that. He's like, I don't understand, because that should be arguing
towards the Christian side of things. Like, yeah, I'll bet you were. And here's all the ways I was
born broken. So, you know, hopefully we can, hopefully we can figure out how to, how to find
Christ to save us from our born brokenness, our conceived brokenness. I mean, so anyway, yeah, I,
I agree. I think there is, and I think there could easily be a genetic predisposition. And I don't
think that has genetic predispositions have no bearing on moral behavior. We know there are
genetic predispositions towards all kinds of things that we would say that everyone would
agree as moral or immoral, or nearly everybody would. And it just doesn't have any bearing. It
doesn't set people free to behave the way they want. If they were born a certain way.
Yeah. You can't just say I have an anger, I have anger issues. Therefore it's okay for me to hit
my wife or my kids. I really like Sam Alberis. The way he says it in his book is God anti-gay.
And this is him speaking from a man with same sex attraction that, that he battles with. He says,
desires for things God has forbidden are a reflection of how sin has distorted me,
not how God has made me. So it's just, that's just that fundamental thing. And I,
and this is where us living in that tension should just wake us up to go.
I, we are all, just like you said, all saved by grace and we are all broken. And so I should
never have, it should free us from having any condescending attitude toward any sin.
Right.
To think like, I would just say things like I would never, or I'm more deserving of salvation
because I haven't done that. And it's just, I don't think you understand, again, your brokenness
or the holiness of God. Like it's, it's like Isaiah pronouncing all these woes on these different
cities. The first few chapters before Isaiah six, and then he sees the Lord and his response is,
woe is me like I'm undone. I'm a dead man. And just like, that's the reality of, you can always
make yourself feel or look better by looking horizontally. And then you see God in his holiness.
You just realize, you know, how awesome, amazing grace is that we're just all,
I just can't believe we're all here. What this book, again, that I referred to earlier was saying,
it's a parenting book and it was talking about your own brokenness doesn't mean you're not
qualified to, to teach the gospel to your kids. It means you're not qualified to teach
moralism to your kids. You've got to be perfect. Like, of course,
I shouldn't be teaching that you've got to be perfect. And then, yeah, it's just a reminder,
like, man, I'm just a center raising centers. And I need, I need all the help that I can get.
Love it. And then just briefly, the argument, are we called, aren't we called to love?
I think rightly prioritize love, but wrongly defines it. Yeah. And
I think that's something that is, is a really hard piece when it comes to having conversations with
people who don't fully understand that because the, the rhetoric and culture is so strong of,
of what love means and that love is affirmation. And, and I've even had conversations with,
and I've even had conversations with, you know, students and friends and pointed out,
like, when it comes to friendship or even my marriage, like I, we never define love as someone
who will never challenge what we say. Like that's, that's never been a proponent of a healthy
relationship in any other way. You know, if I have friends who only tell me what I want to hear and
never push back, then that's that in my mind, they're not actually loving me well and being
good friends. But anyway, so I think, I think we have to unpack a lot of what, what do we mean by
love? Yes. When there is the slap of an enemy than a kiss of a friend, I'm a kiss of a, sorry,
the slap of a friend than the kiss of an enemy. Sorry, I said that backwards. But yeah, we, by,
almost by definition to love someone well will mean speaking the truth to them.
But I think culturally we're moving away from that. I think we have to remind people of that
definition just in general, and even the logic behind it of like, wait, do you, is that actually
what you mean that you want, you know, yeah. And then redefine what biblical love actually is.
Well, that's what strikes me.
Lewis, you know, we, I think we talked about this with when we talked about the problem of pain in
his book, the problem of pain, isn't it called the problem of pain? But he is Lewis. He talks about
this issue in a different way. But like, you wanted this loving God, well, here's what you've got,
you've got a God who loves you so much that he's not going to let you destroy yourself or do things
that are leading in the wrong direction. And so that's what you signed up for. Not this, you know,
kind, benevolent grandfather in the sky who just wants everybody to have a good time. Right. Like,
you wanted love, this is what you're going to get. And that's the same thing with this is we're
loving people. If you're about to drink poison, and it might ruin your afternoon for to hear me
say no, or to knock it out of your hand or whatever, I would, I would not be loving if I knew
what you're doing is wrong. And I don't tell you no, again, this whole issue dealing with your
attitude and how you say it was a big deal. But of course, I just think that the idea that we would
never ever tell anyone they're wrong. I mean, both sides of any issue, you know, believe the
other side is wrong anyway. So you think that that what that means. But yeah, I just think that it's
a misunderstanding, like Bryn said, of what it means to love. Well, and this is the other one that
I'm not, I'm not being naive here. I think there is a difference between love and sex. And so very
often when people say, well, I should be able to love whoever I want. It turns out that doesn't mean
I should because I think I think I know that it would sound like we were being intentionally
obtuse for a Christian to say, well, of course you can. I mean, you were supposed to love our
enemies. We're supposed to love everybody. I'm supposed to love my family. I'm supposed to love
everybody. So no, in no way does the Christian ethic tell you you can't love everybody. You
certainly can. And they say, and so if the response will be, so I'm allowed, I can have sex with them,
say, oh, wait, I thought I thought I thought you were talking primarily about love. But what you
meant was there should be no, no limitations on my behaviors with them, not my attitude toward them.
And, and yeah, so I would say I think sometimes that's a little confusing too, is that Jesus's
ethic was was not merely love, love being loved. That's a, it's a little bit of a silly statement
cognitively to say love is love, or I should be able to love anyone the way I want. Because
obviously we don't, we don't mean that. Because no, I don't know that any population argues
truly fully that. But yeah, so I think I think that's another part of the conversation. And again,
I don't mean to be obtuse. And I know no one's trying to make that necessarily make that argument,
so to speak. But I think that's a good thing to point out. It's still related to a book we've
talked about before by Sam Elbury, Why Does God Care Who I Sleep With? It's the same argument that
goes along with because it is special, because it is important. But I would even add, every parent
knows that because you love your child, you will tell them no, you will put boundaries like you'll
say, no, you can't do that. It's been it's because I love you. And they might not be happy about it.
But it's like, it would be unloving for me to let you just keep doing whatever you want,
if it's self destructive, or, you know, going to harm you in the end, or just wrong. I mean,
so I again, I feel like it's just a misunderstanding of it's a redefining of love and tolerance that
you have to not only can you not say that this is wrong, you actually have to affirm me in it,
which gets even more and more away from what it actually means to love and tolerate someone.
Yeah. And goes back to what we've talked about for months now is a lot of this is, I mean,
it may be hard to accept anyway, but will be even harder to accept if you don't study and understand
the character of God and have that trust that that he said, as you have said, shared the designer
and definer in the first place. Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed
faith. If you enjoyed what you heard, or were challenged, please leave us a review. We'll help
other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist church. Remember, don't give up, trust God, search for answers.
